title: Ethics panel refuses to release internal Maxine Waters report

content_original:
Ethics holds back Waters report

The House Ethics Committee is refusing to publicly release an outside counsel’s findings following a probe into the panel’s handling of the case against Democratic Rep. Maxine Waters (Calif.), saying such a move is not necessary or in line with committee’s rules.

The 10-member Ethics Committee, instead, called Martin’s findings “staff advice” and said there “is no justification for releasing the confidential details of staff advice at this time.”

Story Continued Below

“It is also simply incorrect to assume that Mr. Martin ‘issued’ a ‘report’ in this matter. He did not,” said Friday’s letter from the Ethics Committee. Reps. Bob Goodlatte (R-Va.) and John Yarmuth (D-Ky.) are serving as the acting chairman and ranking Democrat of Ethics during the Waters’ probe. Six other lawmakers, including Reps. Jo Bonner (R-Ala.) and Linda Sanchez (D-Calif.), the chairman and ranking members, have recused themselves from the case, an unprecedented move.

“While his tremendous experience and reputation in the community assure the House and public that the Committee is receiving independent advice, Mr. Martin was retained to advise and assist the committee, as staff to the committee. In that role, Mr. Martin provided confidential and thorough advice to the committee, just as congressional staff advise member and House committees on a daily basis, so that the members and committees may make their own informed findings and conclusions.”

Sixty-nine Democrats, including Waters, sent a letter to the Ethics Committee on Thursday, demanding it release Martin’s findings after the Ethics Committee announced Martin had found no improper conduct in its handling of Waters’ matter. Waters is alleged to have improperly intervened on behalf of a minority bank where her husband owned stock during the 2008 U.S. financial crisis. Waters was hit with three ethics violations in mid-2010, but a trial on the charges was postponed that November as the Ethics Committee bogged down in internal partisan battles.

Martin was retained to conduct his own investigation of the Ethics Committee following a POLITICO report detailing allegations of staff misconduct, including claims that professional staff members were improperly feeding information to GOP lawmakers on the panel, were racially insensitive and had leaked information to the press.

Martin concluded that there were problems with the case, but said it was not enough to prevent the Ethics Committee from taking final action against Waters.
